Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing Atmospheric Gravity Waves and their Effects on the Antarctic Ozone Layer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stratospheric ozone is an important greenhouse gas that also protects the planet's surface from destructive solar ultraviolet radiation. Depletion of the ozone layer occurs through a series of chemical reactions in which ozone molecules are destroyed by reacting with halogens (chlorine, bromine, etc.) with some of the halogens originating from man-made halocarbons. These reactions are enhanced with cold temperatures at stratospheric altitudes. Current computer models are capable estimating the magnitude of ozone hole development in the stratosphere over the polar regions, but the models underestimate the amount of stratospheric cooling as compared to measurements made by ground-based remote-sensing LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) instruments. This project seeks to better understand the role of atmospheric gravity waves in the Earth's stratosphere and their potential effects on the Antarctic ozone layer. Accurate forecasts of the Antarctic ozone hole parameters by coupling atmospheric chemistry and climate models are critical for monitoring ozone hole recovery. This, in turn, is important for understanding whether or not the goals of the Montreal protocol are being met.

The high-resolution Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model will be used to account for effects of atmospheric gravity waves that propagate upward in the lower atmosphere and, therefore, affect atmospheric circulation, stratospheric temperature, and consequently behavior of the Antarctic ozone layer. A number of Antarctic ground-based lidar data (from McMurdo, South Pole, Davis, Syowa stations, and past observations at Rothera Station) will be used to validate and examine the WRF modeling results. The enhanced gravity wave parameterization will be used to run "The Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model" (WACCM) to study the stratospheric circulation and temperatures above Antarctica. This research effort is a cost-effective investment that will advance the state of knowledge of lower atmosphere dynamics and improve or correct parameterization of gravity waves and, thereby, improve models of the lower atmosphere. In turn this will improve understanding of how lower atmosphere processes can affect ozone depletion reactions. The award will support an early career female scientist with her first NSF funding, as well as support an undergraduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this projects are: (1) develop better representations of gravity waves in CCMs, (2) improve a cold-pole problem, and (3) assess the impacts of realistic gravity waves on Antarctic ozone layer using a high-resolution model that resolves small-scale gravity waves. As the co-I (institute PI) of this project, my major goals are : (1) derive and provide gravity wave characteristics from the Iron (Fe) Boltzmann lidar at McMurdo, Antarctica and provide them to the PI; and (2) derive and provide the statistical characteristics of the high-to-medium frequency and mesoscale gravity waves at middle latitude using the Sodium (Na) Doppler lidar in Boulder, Colorado and compare them with the WACCM model for gravity waves in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) region.

The main scientific outcomes of this project are listed as follows: (1) nine years of gravity wave potential energy densities have been derived and used to the study the seasonal and interannual variability of gravity waves in McMurdo, Antarctica; (2) wave characteristics including wave periods, vertical wavelengths and phase speeds are computed and their statistics are documented; (3) high-to-medium frequency and mesoscale gravity waves have been studied statistically using the Na Doppler lidar in Boulder, CO and their characteristics including polarization and dispersion relations have been examined. Supplementing these scientific findings, the temperature data from the TIMED/SABER measurements have been utilized to investigate the global characteristics of gravity waves and planetary waves, and their interannual variabilities. In particular, the global structure of gravity wave potential energy density has been derived using 18 years of SABER data (2002-2019), which provides an valuable dataset to compare with models and study the wave variabilities from days to decades.

This project has significantly enhanced the understanding of wave characteristics and their impacts especially in the polar region. It discovered the equatorial wind pattern (QBO) in the polar waves. The mechanisms for such an equator-to-pole coupling processes have been modeled and studied. It provides ground-truth references to the modeling efforts to simulate atmospheric waves or assess/parameterize small-scale gravity waves. 

The main achievement of this project leads to 19 publications, including 6 peer-reviewed journal papers and 13 conference presentations including numerous invited talks. All the scientific results have been well disseminated and communicated to the community. It has significantly enhanced the understanding of wave dynamics, and wave impacts in the polar region. 

Two female undergraduate students have been trained via working on this project with Dr. Lu. Both of them finished their senior theses with Dr. Lu and were successfully enrolled in graduate schools in US. It has provided Dr. Lu (tenure-track faculty) great opportunities to advise undergraduate students towards the success, launch her group at Clemson University, and strengthen the collaborations with the peers.
